doc.field: Chancellor Kohl arrived Moscow for a three-way summit meeting with Russian President Yeltsin and French President Chirac. He was received at the airport by State Premier Kirijenko. The three politicians want to discuss closer economic and political ties between Russia and the European Union. By best report, the focus of the discussion is on the conditions in the Serbian province of Kosovo and the situation in Iraq. Yeltsin also wants to comment on the recent reorganization of his government. Prior to the summit, Yeltsin had a telephone conference with Chirac and Kohl. The subject of conversation was not revealed.
European currency union expected to start with 11 members

According to a recommendation of the EU-Commission, the European Monetary Union can start with eleven countries at the beginning of next year. According to the commission in Brussels, this will include Germany, France, Belgium, Italy, the Netherlands, Luxembourg, Austria, Ireland, Portugal, Spain and Finland. The European Currency Institute expressed itself with greater reservation. Its president, Deusenberg, explained at the presentation of his report on convergence that in most countries corrections are still necessary. The Euro-readiness of Italy and Belgium in particular are doubted. The Institute also requires further consolidation steps on the part of Germany. Of the 15 European Union states, only Greece did not meet qualifications for monetary union. Britain, Denmark and Sweden do not want to introduce the Euro until later. In Bonn, the government and SPD opposition welcomed both the recommendations. Bavarian State Premier Stoiber said however, in respect to the different evaluations in each of the reports, there are still open questions. Now it is crucial how the concerns of the Currency Institute will be taken into account. In May, the heads of state and government of the EU want to make a final decision on the future membership of the economic and monetary union.
Greens want to call special party conference

Alliance 90/The Greens want to call a special party conference for the beginning of June, on account of their controversial election platform. At this party conference, they will set forth their goals in a short prospectus, said party spokeswoman Mueller to journalists in Bonn. The 5 DM gasoline price has shown for example, that the ideals of the Greens need to be made more understandable to the citizenry. Previously on Deutschlandfunk radio, she had called for party unity on the vote over NATO eastern expansion, and suggested that mutual abstention represents the best way to handle it.
Rexrodt meets with employers and unions on employment

Federal Minister for Economic Affairs Rexrodt participated in a high-level conference with employers and unions on employment, to discuss steps to be taken against unemployment. The goal of the talks is to put into practice the guidelines of the European Union Employment Summit of November 1997. The member states of the European Union had committed themselves there to national measures addressing the long-term unemployment, and youth unemployment.
Parliamentary mediation committee appoints working group

The mediation committee for the Bundestag and Bundesrat appointed a working group on the new general law for universities and colleges. Federal Education Minister Ruettgers said from Bonn the committee will negotiate regarding a temporary restriction on study fees. The CDU politician is opposed to a general ban against these fees. The SPD-dominated Bundesrat had previously expressed support for a national ban to be made into law. The mediation committee will report on the results of its discussions a week from Thursday.

The Book Fair in Leipzig opened this evening. Running through Sunday, the fair features more than 1800 publishers from 34 countries. This represents a new record of participation for the fair. Romania is the featured country.

The Karlsruhe SC football club, in danger of relegation from the National League, has parted ways with their trainer of 12 years, Wenfried Schaefer. According to correspondents in Karlsruhe, Joerg Berger will take up the position as Schaefer's successor.

Scattered clouds to clear in the coming night, and continuing widespread frost between 2 and -9 degrees. Tomorrow, beginning with sunny or light clouds, later heavier clouds in the northwest, and increasing rain in the afternoon off the North Sea. High temperatures between 10 and 13 degrees.
